terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Wyoming mountains. Moderate elevation with mountain scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional WY event. Mountain terrain with remote location, high altitude, and small local field.

biased_opinion.summary: The Mane Event Gravel is a regional event in Wyoming—mountain terrain with moderate elevation and high altitude. The Wyoming mountains are scenic, but the small local field, remote location, and limited organization keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional WY mountain gravel race. Worth it for WY/Mountain West riders. Not worth traveling far for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to WY—yes, it's solid. If you're traveling—skip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better WY races: Dead Swede Gravel, WYO 131, Cowboy Crusher.

logistics.food: Sheridan has full dining options. Stock nutrition.
logistics.official_site: Check The Mane Event Gravel website

course_description.signature_challenge: Wyoming mountains terrain at high altitude.

non_negotiables.why: Wyoming mountains require sustained mountain effort.
Limited aid stations and remote location require self-sufficiency.

marketplace_variables.race_hook_detail: Regional event with mountain terrain and high altitude.

logistics.explanation: Start/finish at Koltiska Pumpkin Patch with rider check-in Friday 4-8pm plus race day registration for late arrivals. Staggered starts manage distance groups from 7:30am (78-mile) to 9:30am (25-mile). Flagged parking and dry camping available but lodging strategy unclear.

length.explanation: 54-mile option at 3,188 feet of climbing hits that awkward middle distance between recreational and serious gravel racing. Four distance options from 25 to 78 miles with staggered wave starts every 30-60 minutes help manage field spread and pacing groups.

technicality.explanation: Jim Rapp describes routes that "take riders onto scenic roadways and rolling hills" through ranch land and sweeping foothills. Course features moderate terrain with "rolling short steep hills or moderate, sustained climbs" on well-maintained county roads without technical drama.

elevation.explanation: The 54-mile climbs 3,188 feet with "a long draw of a climb" mid-race followed by "a long downhill in the last ~15 miles." Rolling ranch country delivers challenging but manageable Wyoming elevation through foothills terrain east of Sheridan.

climate.explanation: 2025 race delivered "wonderful weather" with 52°F at 7:30am start warming to 80°F high and light winds. Rain hit days before but cleared for race day. September in Wyoming can be perfect or harsh — this year riders got lucky.

altitude.explanation: Starting from Sheridan's base elevation around 3,800 feet through rolling ranch country that keeps maximum elevations reasonable. You'll notice it coming from sea level but won't need serious acclimatization for Wyoming foothills terrain.

adventure.explanation: Routes showcase "the untamed beauty of Wyoming" winding through rolling ranch land and sweeping foothills on mostly gravel county roads. Well-marked courses with aid stations every 12-15 miles provide backcountry Wyoming experience with proper support.

prestige.explanation: Gale Vanderpool enjoys "the family-like setting of the race and competitors at the starting point." This charity fundraiser for Sheridan Sundowners Lions Club vision programs draws local community support rather than gravel scene recognition.

race_quality.explanation: Well-marked routes with aid stations every 12-15 miles providing water, electrolytes, and snacks plus sweeper vehicle support. Event features "spirited camaraderie" with organized packet pickup, staggered starts, and finishing medals for all distances.

experience.explanation: Cody Mefford notes the venue provides "a location for families to have fun while their racers challenge themselves" with music and post-race meal. SWAG bags include t-shirt and nutrition products with finishing medals creating pleasant family atmosphere.

community.explanation: Event showcases "spirited camaraderie" and "welcoming community vibe" as the primary fundraiser for Lions Club vision programs. Gale Vanderpool highlights the "family-like setting" while supporting causes like international SightFirst Program to eradicate blindness.

field_depth.explanation: Four distance options with staggered wave starts from 7:30am to 9:30am manage different pace groups. 25-mile results show recreational pace spreads with weekend warrior field averaging 9-16 mph rather than competitive depth.

value.explanation: Entry fees range $70-110 including SWAG bag, post-race meal, t-shirt, finishing medals, and aid station nutrition across 6 support stations. The charity fundraising angle adds purpose beyond riding while keeping pricing reasonable for supported gravel event.

expenses.explanation: Free dry camping available at venue with advance notice — pack in and pack out your gear. Entry fees $70-110 depending on distance with post-race meal included. Sheridan location keeps lodging costs manageable compared to destination gravel events.
